Certain finite Thom spectra

Mar 26, 2019

In the previous post, we focused on the Hopkins-Mahowald theorem, exhibiting as a Thom spectrum over . Here is a silly related observation: is the Thom spectrum of a map that factors through . Namely, since , we can simply choose , and the map classifying . More nontrivially, one can ask if is the Thom spectrum of a map that factors through .

There is a finite spectrum such that , i.e., such that as Steenrod comodules. Let me briefly recall two constructions of this spectrum:

  • Let denote the question mark complex, constructed as the cofiber of the map obtained by choosing a lifting through . Denote by its Spanier-Whitehead dual, which, upon shifting (so that its bottom cell is in dimension zero) can alternatively be constructed the Thom spectrum of the real bundle over determined by the map that’s adjoint to the inclusion . (One can alternatively construct this bundle via clutching functions.) Consider the smash product . Then, the unit and evaluation maps compose to give the map given by multiplication by the Euler characteristic of . It is easy to compute this Euler characteristic: it’s precisely multiplication by . We conclude that splits off of ; let denote the other summand. Then the cohomology of is isomorphic to , so is an example of such a spectrum .

  • The second construction is from Davis-Mahowald’s - and -Periodicity in Stable Homotopy Theory. Consider the suspension spectrum of real projective space; the cell structure of is illustrated below (the bottom cell is in dimension ):

    We can restrict to the bottom cells, and this tells us the cell structure of . Let denote the subcomplex consisting of the cells between dimensions and . Consider the map . Since the multiplication by map on is homotopic to the composite , and is nilpotent, we find that the map factors through the cofiber of the inclusion , i.e., through . Let denote the resulting map. We note that (by James periodicity, or just direct visualization); is the same as the “top four cells of ”, so we’d like to construct a map from into a -cell complex which agrees with the bottom four cells of .

    By direct analysis, we see that the -skeleton of is the same as (a shift of) , so we want a map . Since is the fiber of the map , we would just need to show that the map is zero when projected down to . But if we take the Spanier-Whitehead dual of the composite , then the same argument as above shows that the resulting map is null (so the original map is also null); this gives us the desired map . By calculations with the Adem relations, we find that the cofiber of indeed does have cohomology isomorphic to .

We can now ask the following question: is the Thom spectrum of a spherical fibration (of virtual dimension zero) classified by a map ? Before addressing this question, let’s try to work out some simpler examples.

  • We showed above that the dual question mark complex is indeed a Thom spectrum: it’s associated to a real bundle over .

  • The question mark complex is not a Thom spectrum; see here. Indeed, suppose otherwise, and assume that for a spherical fibration over a space , and write . Let be the Thom class, so that . We know that and . But

    by the Cartan formula. By unstability, , and by dimension considerations, we know that and . Therefore ; contradiction!

  • Along similar lines, the “Joker” is also not a Thom spectrum. This is a -cell complex whose cohomology is is the quotient of the Steenrod algebra by the left ideal generated by and for ; it’s constructed using the Toda bracket . Suppose that for a spherical fibration over a space , and write . Let be the Thom class, so that . We know that and . Moreover, . Therefore:

That was some painful algebra, so let’s summarize what we’ve found. The cohomology of is of the form , where and . (We haven’t said anything about the action of on , i.e., what should be.)

So far, we’ve only looked at the -module structure on ; it’s now time to bring in the entire -module structure. As shown in Figure 1.1 of this paper, there are four different refinements of the -module structure on to an -module structure. In each of these refinements, is nonzero on the class in dimension , i.e., ; in other words, . But by the Cartan relations and unstability. Since , it follows that . In particular, cannot vanish; this rules out the spectra denoted and in loc. cit. as being Thom spectra.

Since , we need . It follows that

which is a contradiction (since cannot vanish)! In particular, we find the (perhaps disappointing?) fact that is not the Thom spectrum of a spherical fibration (of virtual dimension zero) classified by a map . I expect the same to be true of the spectra , but proving it seems like a real pain.
